articles.headline: Women's Rights Laws and African Custom Clash
articles.snippet: In theory, what happened to 14-year-old Sibongile in this hilly, crowded township outside Durban in November could not happen today -- at least, not legally.     On a broiling Saturday morning, as more than a dozen women looked on, Sibongile joine...
articles.abstract: In theory, what happened to 14-year-old Sibongile in this hilly, crowded township outside Durban in November could not happen today -- at least, not legally.     On a broiling Saturday morning, as more than a dozen women looked on, Sibongile joined 56 other Zulu girls outside a red-and-white striped tent. One by one, they lay on a straw mat beneath the tent; one by one, they received a cursory inspection of their genitals by a woman in a ceremonial beaded hat. As the inspector pronounced judgment on the state of each girl's hymen -- ''virgin,'' ''nice,'' ''perfect'' -- each departed to the excited trilling of the women who were observers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAMONTVILLE, South Africa - In theory, what happened to 14-year-old Sibongile in this hilly, crowded township outside Durban in November could not happen today -- at least, not legally.

articles.headline: A Clever Tax Strategy May Backfire
articles.snippet: THERE is a long-running game involving Wall Street and the Internal Revenue Service. Wall Street figures out ways for investors to get cash without paying taxes. The government eventually gets upset and changes the rules.     Such rule changes do ...
articles.abstract: THERE is a long-running game involving Wall Street and the Internal Revenue Service. Wall Street figures out ways for investors to get cash without paying taxes. The government eventually gets upset and changes the rules.     Such rule changes do not especially bother Wall Street, because brokerage firms can then look for ways around the new rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: THERE is a long-running game involving Wall Street and the Internal Revenue Service. Wall Street figures out ways for investors to get cash without paying taxes. The government eventually gets upset and changes the rules.

articles.headline: Drier, Tainted Nevada May Be Legacy of Gold Rush
articles.snippet: Just outside the chasm of North America's biggest open-pit gold mine there is an immense oasis in the middle of the Nevada desert. It is an idyllic and isolated spot where migratory birds often alight for a stopover. But hardly anything is natural...
articles.abstract: Just outside the chasm of North America's biggest open-pit gold mine there is an immense oasis in the middle of the Nevada desert. It is an idyllic and isolated spot where migratory birds often alight for a stopover. But hardly anything is natural about it.     This is water pumped from the ground by Barrick Gold of Toronto to keep its vast Goldstrike mine from flooding, as the gold company, the world's third largest, carves a canyon 1,600 feet below the level of northern Nevada's aquifer.
articles.lead_paragraph: ELKO, Nev. - Just outside the chasm of North America's biggest open-pit gold mine there is an immense oasis in the middle of the Nevada desert. It is an idyllic and isolated spot where migratory birds often alight for a stopover. But hardly anything is natural about it.

articles.headline: Intel Plans to Shift Focus to Consumer Products
articles.snippet: Intel, the world's biggest chip maker, is breaking away from its longstanding love affair with pure computing power to remake itself as a consumer-friendly brand that will seek to dominate the digital home.      Intel's strategy, based on a new ge...
articles.abstract: Intel, the world's biggest chip maker, is breaking away from its longstanding love affair with pure computing power to remake itself as a consumer-friendly brand that will seek to dominate the digital home.      Intel's strategy, based on a new generation of multimedia platforms and chips, will be unveiled next week at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. For consumers, the technology shift will mean laptop computers with longer battery life and computers that will become digital entertainment hubs in the living room.
articles.lead_paragraph: Intel, the world's biggest chip maker, is breaking away from its longstanding love affair with pure computing power to remake itself as a consumer-friendly brand that will seek to dominate the digital home.

articles.headline: Overseas, the Trains and the Market for Them Accelerate
articles.snippet: Even more high-speed trains? Europe must be kidding.     In one vast hall, workers in blue overalls are putting the finishing touches on what would, on an old-fashioned train, be a locomotive, except that it houses a spacious conference room with ...
articles.abstract: Even more high-speed trains? Europe must be kidding.     In one vast hall, workers in blue overalls are putting the finishing touches on what would, on an old-fashioned train, be a locomotive, except that it houses a spacious conference room with a large table and seven comfortable armchairs.
articles.lead_paragraph: KREFELD, Germany - Even more high-speed trains? Europe must be kidding.

articles.headline: G.I.'s to Increase U.S. Supervision of Iraqi Police
articles.snippet: American commanders are planning to increase significantly the number of soldiers advising Iraqi police commando units, in part to curtail abuse that the units are suspected of inflicting on Sunni Arabs, a senior commander in Iraq said Thursday.  ...
articles.abstract: American commanders are planning to increase significantly the number of soldiers advising Iraqi police commando units, in part to curtail abuse that the units are suspected of inflicting on Sunni Arabs, a senior commander in Iraq said Thursday.     Under the plan, which the officer said he expected would be formally approved in a few weeks, the number of advisers working with the Iraqi units would be greatly expanded. The advisers themselves would be under the command of American officers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 29 - American commanders are planning to increase significantly the number of soldiers advising Iraqi police commando units, in part to curtail abuse that the units are suspected of inflicting on Sunni Arabs, a senior commander in Iraq said Thursday.

articles.headline: His Car Smelling Like French Fries, Willie Nelson Sells Biodiesel
articles.snippet: Willie Nelson drives a Mercedes.      But do not lose faith, true believers. The exhaust from Mr. Nelson's diesel-powered Mercedes smells like peanuts, or French fries, or whatever alternative fuel happens to be in his tank.
articles.abstract: Willie Nelson drives a Mercedes.      But do not lose faith, true believers. The exhaust from Mr. Nelson's diesel-powered Mercedes smells like peanuts, or French fries, or whatever alternative fuel happens to be in his tank.

articles.headline: U.S. Growth May Hinge on Businesses
articles.snippet: The housing market is gradually fading as a prop for the economy, eroding a source of increased wealth that allowed consumers to borrow and spend avidly in recent years.      Meanwhile, the bond market, where short-term interest rates are now slig...
articles.abstract: The housing market is gradually fading as a prop for the economy, eroding a source of increased wealth that allowed consumers to borrow and spend avidly in recent years.      Meanwhile, the bond market, where short-term interest rates are now slightly above long-term rates in what is known as an inverted yield curve, suggests that the economy is headed for a sharp slowdown, perhaps even a recession. The stock market rally earlier this year has petered out.
articles.lead_paragraph: The housing market is gradually fading as a prop for the economy, eroding a source of increased wealth that allowed consumers to borrow and spend avidly in recent years.

articles.headline: Internet Sales Show Big Gains Over Holidays
articles.snippet: Online retailers, whose growth was expected to level off after a decade of dizzying gains, experienced a stellar holiday season, according to two preliminary reports released yesterday, as traditional stores like Wal-Mart and Target cemented their...
articles.abstract: Online retailers, whose growth was expected to level off after a decade of dizzying gains, experienced a stellar holiday season, according to two preliminary reports released yesterday, as traditional stores like Wal-Mart and Target cemented their place on the Web.     Consumer spending online reached $18.1 billion in November and December, a 25 percent increase over 2004, according to the research firm ComScore Networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Online retailers, whose growth was expected to level off after a decade of dizzying gains, experienced a stellar holiday season, according to two preliminary reports released yesterday, as traditional stores like Wal-Mart and Target cemented their place on the Web.
